content.description: In humans, one allele of the <math alttext="A P O E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene, called <math alttext="A P O E epsilon 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>E</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mi>ε</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, can result in a high tolerance of cholesterol. Cholesterol is a vital substance for humans but may lead to heart disease in an older adult with a history of high cholesterol diets. High cholesterol diets are becoming more prevalent in the United States. Currently only about 2% of humans carry the <math alttext="A P O E epsilon 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>E</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mi>ε</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> allele.

choices.label: The <math alttext="A P O E epsilon 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>E</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mi>ε</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> allele was the result of chance mutations so it is not possible to predict how its frequency will change in the future.

The low frequency of the <math alttext="A P O E epsilon 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>E</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mi>ε</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> allele indicates it is probably a recessive allele, so it will become less frequent as the dominant allele becomes more frequent.
